NFL Data Analytics

Michael DeMarco · Thomas Jurgens · Jonathan David ·

Our goal was to utilize various data sources to create an accurate machine-learning model
that can predict game outcomes with key NFL metrics.

Data Analysis

Data Processing
  • Mining data sources (Kaggle, dynamic NFL stat trackers, and betting information resources) through web-scraping and producing .csv/.xlsx files
  • Cleaning, organizing, and removing non-logical data to establish correlations
  • Incorporate feasible data patterns to test and train our ML model to predict successful game outcomes
  • Dynamically update model based on upcoming and future games

Tools and technologies utilized

Interactive Data

Instructions: Select desired team from NFL schedule graphic below and choose valid matchups for accurate model filtering

Machine Learning

Machine Learning Overview
  • Through our initial efforts we identified Expected Points Added (EPA) as a highly correlated statistic in predicting team points scored
  • Used a logistic regression model, stemming from our EPA logic, to produce a model that predicts wins and losses.
  • In this logistic regression model, the features included offensive and defensive EPA averages over a window of previous games, as well as external factors, such as vegas spread and total lines

ML Correlation Plot

Overview of which statistics drive outcome. Expected Points Added (EPA)
appeared to be a large data driver.

Home EPA vs Points

Direct correlation between higher EPA values and total points scored shown here.

Away EPA vs Points

Second instance of the direct correlation between higher EPA values and total points scored shown here.
